conclusion: Variable linear motion means the velocity is changing, which appears as a non-horizontal line on a v-t graph.
From t = 0 to t = 1 s: The velocity is constant at v = 2 m/s (horizontal line)
From t = 1 to t = 2 s: The velocity decreases linearly from v = 2 m/s to v = 0 m/s (sloped line)
From t = 2 to t = 3 s: The velocity continues decreasing linearly from v = 0 m/s to v = -2 m/s (sloped line)

premise: From t = 0 to t = 1 s: The velocity is constant at v = 2 m/s (horizontal line)
conclusion: In the interval t = 0 to t = 1 s: No change in velocity (constant)

premise: From t = 1 to t = 2 s: The velocity decreases linearly from v = 2 m/s to v = 0 m/s (sloped line)
conclusion: In the interval t = 1 to t = 2 s: Velocity is changing (decreasing)

premise: From t = 2 to t = 3 s: The velocity continues decreasing linearly from v = 0 m/s to v = -2 m/s (sloped line)
conclusion: In the interval t = 2 to t = 3 s: Velocity is changing (decreasing)

premise: In the interval t = 0 to t = 1 s: No change in velocity (constant)
conclusion: t = 0 to t = 1 s: a = 0 (no acceleration)

premise: In the interval t = 1 to t = 2 s: Velocity is changing (decreasing)
conclusion: t = 1 to t = 2 s: a = -2 m/s² (negative acceleration/deceleration)

premise: In the interval t = 2 to t = 3 s: Velocity is changing (decreasing)
conclusion: t = 2 to t = 3 s: a = -2 m/s² (negative acceleration)

premise: In the interval t = 1 to t = 3 s: Velocity is changing (decreasing)
conclusion: Yes, the particle did undergo variable linear motion in the first 3 seconds. Specifically, from t = 1 s to t = 3 s, the velocity was changing at a constant rate (constant deceleration). Only during the interval from t = 0 to t = 1 s was the motion uniform (constant velocity).
